title: Default Ubuntu 22.04 Directory Layout + Root Terminal Access
context: Examining Ubuntuâ€™s post-installation filesystem structure (with ownership and symlinks), and learning how to open a terminal with elevated privileges.
keyIdea: Ubuntu 22.04 uses a merged /usr structure with symlinks from /bin, /lib, and /sbin; ownership defaults to root:root. Root access should be obtained via sudo for individual commands or sudo -i for a shell session.
commands:
# List root directories with symlinks and permissions
sudo ls -ld /* | sort

# Enter a temporary root shell
sudo -i

# Run individual commands with root privileges
sudo <command>

# Exit root shell
exit
explanation: The merged /usr layout simplifies system management by unifying executable and library locations. Root ownership and permissions protect system integrity. sudo enables secure privilege escalation without persistent root login.

reusabilityNotes.whenToReuse: When auditing filesystem layouts, verifying permissions, or performing administrative tasks.
reusabilityNotes.pitfalls: Avoid making global permission changes as root. Never run sudo commands that affect /proc, /sys, or /run unless you know the effect.
